Quhen  Wiliame  Walas  dyd  his  payne, 
To  suecoure  the  Kynrik  of  Scotland."  r 

He  was  slain  in  1297.     He  left  two  sons,  of  whom  John  the  younger  was  ancestor 

of  the  De  Moravias  of  Drurasargard  and  Abercairney  ;  the  eldest  was 

Sir  Andrew  Moray  of  Bothwell,  the  illustrious  Wardane  of  Scotland  ;  he  died  in 

1338 ;— 

"  Oure  the  Mownth  than  passit  he 
Til  Avawch  in  his  awyne  cuntre, 
And  thare  than  endyt  he  his  dayis. 


In  the  Kyrk  cathedyrale  of  Rosmarkyne 
That  nobil  Knycht  wes  enteryde  syne."8 

He  married  Christian,  the  sister  of  Bruce,  and  held  the  office  of  Panetarius  Regis, 
which  was  also  held  in  succession  by  his  two  sons,  John  and  Thomas. 

John,  the  eldest  son,  along  with  his  great  southern  possessions,  retained  the  antient 
family  lands  of  Artrillie  and  Croy,  out  of  which  he  endowed  a  chaplainrie  in  the 
cathedral  church  of  Elgin,  for  the  soul  of  his  father  of  good  memory,  Sir  Andrew  de 
Moravia,  in  1351. l  He  seems  to  have  died  without  issue,  as  both  his  office  and 
estates  came  to  his  brother, 

Thomas  de  Moravia,  who  confirmed  the  grant  of  John  to  the  church  of  Moray, 
in  1353,"  and  died  in  1361,  while  in  England  as  one  of  the  hostages  for  King 
David  II.     He  left  an  only  child, 

Joan,  who  carried  the  estates  of  Bothwell  and  the  possessions  in  the  North  to 
Archibald  third  Earl  of  Douglas. 

The  pedigrees  of  these  three  lines  of  De  Moravia  may  be  said  to  be  proved  from 
this  Register.  In  the  preceding  statement  two  generations  may  be  thrown  into  one, 
or  a  single  life  divided ;  but  there  cannot  be  any  doubt  with  regard  to  the  general 
line  of  descent  of  each,  and  their  mutual  connexion.  A  more  extensive  and  accurate 
investigation  will  assuredly  remove  the  obscurity  that  surrounds  the  first  two  des- 
cents,  and  supply  information  of  several  marriages  and  collateral  descendants.  Such 
an  enquiry,  properly  conducted,  can  hardly  fail  also  to  throw  light  on  the  interesting 
but  obscure  subject  of  the  history  of  the  Earldoms  of  Stratherne  and  Caithness,  in 
both  of  which  the  several  lines  of  De  Moravia  were  nearly  interested.

1  ULIBARDYN. 


With  regard  to  the  remaining  branches  of  this  great  tree,  there  are  no  docu- 
ments  yet  discovered  to  enable  us  to  fix  their  precise  point  of  springing  ;  and  all  that 
the  present  Register,  with  its  appendix,  can  be  said  to  have  done  in  this  respect, 
is  to  have  brougbt  it  somewhat  nearer  demonstration,  that  the  De  Moravias  of  Tuli- 
bardyn  and  Atholl  are  of  the  same  common  stock  with  the  houses  whose  descent  is 
stated  above. 
family  oi  The  first  ascertained  person  of  the  Perthshire  family  of  Tulibardyn,  is  Johannes 

de  Moravia,  or  John  de  Murreve,  sheriff  of  Perth  in  the  reign  of  Alexander  II.  x 
What  were  his  Perthshire  possessions,  or  his  connexion  with  that  county,  is  quite 
unknown.  It  is  most  probable,  as  is  commonly  asserted,  that  he  left  a  son — Sir 
Malcolm  de  Moravia,  who  was  also  sheriff  of  Perthshire,  and  fiourished  mostly  in  the 
reign  of  Alexander  III.  y  He  is  said  to  have  witnessed  a  charter  in  the  36th  year 
of  Alexander  III,1  and  he  was  dead  before  1286."  He  had  two  sons,  John,b  who 
probably  left  no  heirs,  and  Sir  William. 

Sir  William  de  Moravia,  knight,  inherited  lands  in  Moray  from  his  father  Sir 
Malcolm.  He  married  Ada,  the  daughter  of  Malis,  steward  of  the  Earldom  of 
Stratherne  ;  and  by  that  marriage,  together  perhaps  with  some  previous  connexion 
with  the  great  family  of  the  Earls  of  Stratherne,  he  acquired  Tulibardyn,  and  other 
estates  in  Perthshire.  From  him  the  descent  of  the  Morays  of  Tulibardyn  and 
Atholl  is  clear  and  well  evidenced. 

The  evidence  of  their  Northern  origin  may  be  shortly  stated.  We  find  Sir 
Malcolm  de  Moravia  proprietor  of  the  lands  of  Lambride,  near  Elgin,  which  he  gave 
to  his  son  William  by  a  charter,  that  from  the  names  of  all  the  witnesses,  must 
have  been  executed  at  Elgln. c  Freskinus  de  Moravia  of  Duffus,  and  his  connexion 
Sir  Reginald  le  Chen,  seem  to  have  visited  him  in  Perthshire,  and  are  witnesses 
along  with  Sir  Malcolm  in  a  charter  of  Malis  Earl  of  Stratherne. 

John,  the  son  of  Sir  Malcolm,  was  possessed  of  lands  in  Strathbolgy,  which  he 
o-ranted  to  his  brother  William  ;d  and  these  were  held  of  William,  Earl  of  Sutherland, 
the  head  of  the  house. 

Sir  William  de  Moravia,  the  son  of  Sir  Malcolm,  acquired  by  marriage  the  lands  of 

*  Chy.  ofArbr.  N.  214,  215.  b  App.  8. 
y  App.  7.  c  App.  7. 

*  Douglas.  d  App.  8. 
a  App.  8. 


Tulibardync  in  Perthshire.  It  is  difficult  to  hold  it  a  mere  aceidental  coincidence, 
that,  on  the  banks  of  the  Lossy,  in  the  midst  of  the  possessions  of  the  Northern  De 
Moravias,  a  small  property  bore  the  same  name  of  Tulibardyn  so  early  as  the  epis- 
copate  of  Andrew  de  Moravia,  who  died  in  1242. f  It  is  now  perhaps  impossible  to 
say  which  of  these  places,  so  distant  from  each  other,  first  bore  the  name,  but  that 
one  was  named  from  the  other  is  at  least  probable.  Such  an  importation  of  the 
name  of  some  favourite  former  residence  has  been  at  all  times  common  in  Scotland, 
and  frequently  confounds  the  modern  topographer.  It  is  here  immaterial  to  settle 
the  question  of  precedency,  since  the  inference  of  the  connexion  of  the  Perthshire 
family  with  that  of  Morayshire  arises  equally,  whether  the  name  was  transplanted 
from  Stratherne  to  Elgin,  or  from  the  banks  of  the  Lossy  to  Perthshire.  s 

'  Thc  ascertained  pcdigree  of  the  ancestor  of  Tulibardyn  and  of  his  wife  is  as  follows  : —

the  Morays 
of  Tulibardyn. 

'  N.  27. 

e  The  low  country  of  Moray  affords  several 
instances  of  names  of  places  imported  by  settlers 
from  other  distriets ;  as  Dalvey,  on  the  west 
bank  of  Fmdhorn,  from  a  place  of  the  same 
name  in  Strathspey  ;  Inverugie  from  the  castle 
of  the  Keiths  in  Buchan ;  Inchbrok,  probably 
from  a  place  in  the  De  Moravias  barony 
in  Linlithgow.  It  is  certain  the  Morayshire 
place  of  Tulibardyn  bore  that  name  before 
1242.  We  have  no  evidence  of  the  De  Moravias 
having  property  in  Stratherne  at  so  early  a 
period.  But  we  find  tlie  grandfather  of  Ada 
the  wife  of  Sir  William  de  Moravia,  possessed 
of  "  that  town  of  Katherlauenach  called  Tuli- 
"  bardyn"  before  1234  (App.  10).     It  is  possi- 


ble  that  the  father  or  grandfather  of  Sir  William, 
of  whose  property  we  know  nothing,  but  who, 
being  sheriffs  of  Perthshire,  must  have  had  lands 
there,  and  who  appear  to  have  been  early  con- 
nected  with  the  district  of  Stratherne  and  with 
the  family  of  its  Earls,  may  have  brought  that 
name  into  Perthshire,  though  not  then  pro- 
prietors  of  the  place  so  named :  or  otherwise, 
the  Perthshire  family,  still  maintaining,  as  we 
have  seen,  their  connexion  with  the  north,  may 
have  carried  into  Moray  the  name  of  their  re- 
sidence,  or  of  the  seat  of  their  new  connex- 
ions. 

«  Muriel's  seal,  given  ineorrectly  by  Sir  G.  Mackenzie 
{herahlry),  is  eograved  at  the  end  of  tlie  preface  from  an 
Impression  attached  to  App.  13.  Her  arms  are  the  cheverons 
of  the  Earls  of  Stratherne. 


The  identity  of  the  name  may  not  go  far  in  a  proof  of  connexion  of  two  families. 
But  the  identity  of  name  and  arms  together  appears  to  provc,  uther  that  the  families 
are  connected,  or  that  the  early  branches  of  one  of  them  chose  to  have  it  so  believed. 
Of  the  arms  of  the  first  two  generations  of  the  Perthshire  De  Moravias,  we  have  no 
evidence.  No  monuments  or  seals  of  theirs  are  preserved.  John,  the  son  of  Sir 
Malcolm,  did  not  display  on  his  seal  any  shield  or  coat-armour.  His  badge  or  cog- 
nizance  was  a  bull  passant.  If  any  allusion  was  there  made  to  his  descent,  it  is  per- 
haps  to  be  found  in  a  star  placed  over  the  bull's  back.h  But  from  the  time  when 
any  heraldic  bearing  was  introduced  among  them,  the  Perthshire  De  Moravias  and 
all  their  cadets  have  borne  the  same  arms  with  the  Northern  family.  It  is  true, 
indeed,  that  the  tincturcs  of  the  arms  of  the  Southern  families  of  the  name  of  Moray 
differ  from  those  of  the  family  of  Sutherland,  and  from  each  other;  but  it  is  to  be 
observed,  that  the  only  authentic  evidence  of  early  heraldry,  the  sculpture  of  tombs 
and  other  buildings,  and  seals, '  furnish  no  inforrr.ation  regarding  the  tinctures  of 
the  blazoning.  It  must  be  remembered  also,  that  in  Scotland  at  least,  a  change  of 
tinctures  has  been,  from  a  very  early  period,  a  favourite  mode  of  differencing  the 
arms  of  cadets. 

The  three  stars,  forming  the  charge  of  the  arms  of  some  of  the  earliest  settled 
families  of  Moray,k  has  given  rise  to  the  notion  that  this  was  originally  the  arms 
of  the  province.  There  is  no  reason,  however,  to  believe  that  any  district  in  Scot- 
land  claimed  anciently  a  peculiar  coat  of  arms  distinct  from  that  of  the  lords  of 
the  territory ;  and  it  seems  more  natural  to  conclude,  that  one  family  of  great  pos- 
sessions  and  power,  having  adopted  arms  at  the  first  introduction  of  heraldry,  was 
readily  followed  and  imitated  by  its  connexions,  dependants,  and  neighbours.  This 
has  certainly  happened  in  other  districts  of  Scotland  ; '  and  when  we  consider  the 
vast  possessions  of  the  first  descendants  of  Freskinus,  we  may  easily  conceive  their 
influence  in  Moray  to  have  been  little  less  than  if  they  had  been  the  territorial  lords 
of  the  province. 

h  One  seal  of  Johu  de   Moravia  (affixed  to  k  The  Inneses,  Brodies,  &c. 

App.  N.  7.)  is  preserved  in  the  Duke  of  AtholTs  '  As  in  Annandalc,  where  the  Saltier  of  the 

charter-room.   Another  impression,  in  the  Chap-  Bruees  became  the  favourite  bearing ;  in  Dou- 

ter-house  at  Durham,  is  engraved  in  Raine's  glasdale,  the  stars  of  Douglas  ;  in  the  Western 

Durham.  Isles  and  Highlands,  the  galley  of  the  Lords  of 

1  This  is  spoken  only  in  regard  to  Scotland,  tlie  Isles ;  and  in  the  country  of  the  Stewards, 

where  there  is  no  ancient  painted  glass  nor  illu-  their  fcss  checque. 
minated  MSS.  of  heraldry. 


But  if  the  evidence  that  the  Morays  of  Atholl  sprang  from  the  northern  stock  he 
held  conclusive,  tlie  more  difficult  question  remains  bebind,  at  what  point  they 
branched  off.  It  would  be  idle  to  offcr  a  conjecturc  regarding  a  matter  which  may 
yct  bc  fully  ascertained,  were  it  not  that  it  may  perliaps  serve  to  throw  some 
ligbt,  or  poiut  the  way  for  future  researches.  We  find  that  Gilbert,  the  Arcb- 
deacon  of  Moray,  afterwards  Bishop  of  Caithness,  had  two  brothers,  Richard  de 
Moravia  of  Culbin,  to  whom  he  gave  the  lands  of  Skelbo  before  1235,  and  John,m  of 
whom  no  more  is  known  with  certainty.  The  date  of  this  personage  would  precisely 
agree  with  the  first  appearance  of  John  de  Moravia,  the  first  of  that  surname  in 
Pcrthshire  ;  and  the  rank  of  his  connexions  might  account  for  him  and  his  immediate 
descendants  so  soon  taking  the  station  which  they  appear  to  havc  held  in  that  coun- 
try.  Unfortunately  we  are  again  left  to  conjecture  what  was  the  parentage  of 
Gilbert  the  Archdeaeon  himself ;  for  although  it  is  plain  from  the  terms  of  the 
charter  of  Hugo  Freskyn,  and  from  other  circumstances,  that  he  was  nearly  related 
to  the  chief  family  of  De  Moravia,  we  nowhere  find  the  name  of  his  father,  or  ofany 
of  his  relatives,  except  the  two  brothers  above-mentioned.  In  the  absence  of  better 
authorities,  we  are  induced  to  trust  to  an  anonymous  scribe,  who  has  noted  on  the 
margin  of  the  oldcr  chartulary,  at  a  deed  of  Gilbert,  Bishop  of  Caithness : n

rians.     All  we  know  of  him  for  certain  is  that  "  hinc  ad  episcopatum  Cathenertsem  provexit ;  et 

he  was  Archdeacon  of  Moray,  apparcntly  during  "  modo  sanctus  miraculis   claret." — (Goodatf, 

the  whole  episcopate  of  Bisliop  Bricius,  1203-  p.  478).     This  was  a  sufficient  foundation  for 


DE  MORAVIA 
AND  DOUGLA 


Before  finally  leaving  this  subject,   it  must    be  allowed    briefly   to  notice  the 
"  indication  of  an  early  connexion  between  this  great  family  and  the  illustrious  house 
of  Douglas. 


Boece,  who,  after  repeating  Fordun's  account 
of  the  Couneil  of  Northampton,  and  the  pas- 
sionaie  defence  of  the  liberties  of  the  Scottish 
Church  by  the  Clerk  Gilbert,  adds — "  Gilbertus 
"  hic  postea  effectus  Episcopus  Cathenensis,"  and 
he  is  followed  by  Leslie,  Camerarius,  Dempster, 
and  Spotiswoode.  It  is  edifying  to  observe  how 
the  mistake  grows  in  its  progress,  until  we 
tind  Balfour,  with  a  glorious  contempt  of  con- 
sistency  and  dates,  setting  down  in  1 1 78,  "  This 
"  yeir,  also,  K.  William  made  Gilbert,  a  learned 
"  man,  Chamberlane  of  Scotland,  and  Bis.  of 
"  Cathnes :  This  is  that  Gilbert  that  stood  out 
"  so  stifly  for  the  liberty  of  the  Church  of  Scot- 
"  land  against  Roger,  Archbis.  of  York,  and 
"  all  the  prelats  of  England." — (Annals).  Now 
if  we  suppose  the  champion  of  the  Scottish 
Clmrch  against  the  prelates  of  England  in  1 176, 
to  have  been  but  thirty  years  of  age,  he  must 
have  been  seventy-six  years  old  when  Gilbert  de 
Moravia  was  made  Bishop  of  Caithness,  and 
about  one  hundred  when  he  died.  If  we  join  to 
this  the  inconsisteney  of  attributing  a  rapid  rise 
in  otfices  of  Church  and  State  to  the  distinguish- 
ed  part  he  took  in  the  Council, — while  it  would 
appear  that  Gilbert  de  Moravia's  promotion  to 
the  Bishopric  took  place  forty-six  years  after 
the  date  of  tliat  Couucil, — it  seems  plain  that 
these  were  diflerent  persons ;  and  it  is  probable 
that  the  coincidenee  of  the  name  of  Gilbert  was 
the  only  foundation  for  joining  the  acts  of  both 
to  swell  the  character  of  one  saint. 

While  it  would  appear  then,  that  Gilhert  de 
Moravia  must  renounce  the  honour  of  having 
vindicated  the  independence  of  the  Scottish 
Church,  it  seems  also  doubtful  whether  he  held 
the  oflfice  of  Chamberlain  of  Scotland.  Though 
occurring  repeatedly  hoth  as  a  granter  and  as  a 
witness  of  charters,  he  nowhere  bears  this  style, 
nor  does  any  Chamberlain  appear  of  the  namc  of 
Gilbert  in  any  authentic  instrument  till  long 


after  his  death.  The  venerable  breviary  of 
Aberdeen  and  the  older  legends  are  in  this  mat- 
ter  better  guides  than  our  old  historians,  since, 
in  the  midst  of  popular  tales  of  miracles,  they  at 
least  avoid  great  historical  anachronisms.  We 
learn  from  them  that  Saint  Gilbert  was  of  a  nohle 
Scotch  family  ;  that  he  was  in  great  favour  with 
King  William  and  Alexander  II.  ;  by  whom,  it 
is  said,  he  was  emplcyed  in  administering  the 
atfairs  of  government  in  the  North  of  Scotland, 
and  especially  in  building  and  fortifying  casfles 
for  the  security  of  the  district.  This  part  of 
the  history  may  have  been  introduced  only  to 
ground  a  story  of  the  miraculous  recovery  of 
certain  account-books,  after  they  had  been  burnt 
by  some  of  his  enemies  ;  and  it  is  very  probable 
that  there  is  no  other  foundation  for  the  asser- 
tion  of  his  having  becn  high  Chamberlain.  It 
may  readily  be  conceived,  however,  that  in  a 
district  just  reclaimed  from  foreign  rulc,  this 
new  Bishop,  nearly  connected  wlth  the  great 
lords  of  the  territory,  must  have  eujoyed  con- 
siderable  power ;  and  we  receive  without  scruple 
the  statement  of  the  legeuds,  that  he  exercised 
his  influence  with  Alexander  to  mitigate  the 
punishment  of  the  people  of  Caithuess  for  the 
murder  of  Adam,  his  predcccssor,  and  that  he 
was  entrusted  with  the  building  of  fortresses  for 
the  protection  of  the  country,  while  he  certain- 
ly  founded  the  Cathedral  Chureh  at  Dornoch. 
His  miracles  are  not  distiuguished  by  any  ori- 
ginality,  if  we  except  the  singular  boon  confer- 
red  by  him  on  a  certain  tenant  of  salmon-fish- 
eries,  who,  in  despair  at  the  unproductiveness  of 
the  season,  and  the  approach  of  rent-day,  intreat- 
ed  the  Saint  to  wash  his  hauds  in  the  river ;  whieh 
was  no  sooner  done  than  an  abundant  draught  of 
fish  repaid  his  faith.  Saint  Gilbert  died  on  the 
lst  April,  1245,  and  is  said  to  have  been  buried 
under  the  central  towcr  of  his  own  Cathedral. 


Wyntoun,  who  is  seldomer  led  away  by  his  imagination  than  most  poets  and 
chroniclers,  has  stated  the  matter  very  much  as  it  now  stands,  in  spite  of  the 
researches  and  supcrior  means  of  infbrmation  of  three  centuries  : — 

"  Of  Mnrrawe  and  the  Dowglas 

"  How  that  thare  begynnyng  was, 

"  Syn  syndry  men  spekis  syndryly, 

"  I  can  put  that  in  na  story. 

"  Bot  in  thare  armeys  bath  thai  bere 

"  The  Sternys  set  in  lyk  manere : 

"  Til  mony  men  it  is  yhit  sene 

"  Apperand  lyk,  that  they  had  bene 

"  Of  kyn,  be  descens  lyneale 

"  Or  be  branchys  collaterale."  P 

The  fabulous  antiquity  of  Sholto  Douglas,  the  contemporary  of  King  Selvathius, 
and  his  imaginary  descendants,  has  been  long  abandoned  with  the  other  fables  of 
Scotch  pedigree.  It  seems  now  to  be  ascertained  that  the  family  took  its  origin,  or 
at  least  assumed  its  territorial  surname,  towards  the  end  of  the  twelfth  century. 
Only  one  or  two  generations  had  passed,  producing  persons  of  no  consideration  for 
rank  or  possessions,  when  a  son  of  the  family  is  found  transplanted  from  his  paternal 
country,  and  the  little  cell  of  Lesmahagow,  of  which  he  had  been  Prior,  to  the 
distant  and  semi-barbarous  but  great  diocese  of  Moray,  of  which  he  was  first  Dean, 
and  subsequently  Bishop.  Such  promotion  was  not  at  that  time  the  result  merely 
of  court  favour.  The  election  appears  to  have  been  in  the  clergy  of  the  diocese ; 
and  after  all  allowance  for  merit  in  the  successful  candidate,  it  seems  to  indicate 
some  connexion  with  leading  persons  of  the  district.  The  only  person  between  whom 
and  the  new  Bishop  a  precise  affinity  is  stated,  is  a  certain  Freskinus  de  Kerdal,  who 
is  styled  by  the  Bishop  "  avunculus  noster  ;"  all  we  know  of  whom  is,  that  he  had  con- 
siderable  possessions  in  the  immediate  neighbourhood  of  the  territories  of  the  family 
of  De  Moravia ;  and  it  may  be  allowed  to  conjecture,  from  the  peculiarity  of  his  name, 
that,  if  not  a  member,  he  was  at  least  a  relative  of  that  family.  When  Bricius 
became  coniiectid  with  the  Diocese,  he  appears  to  have  brought  with  him  a  band  of 
brothers,  who  all  figure  during  his  episcopate  and  that  of  his  successor.  Many  of 
these  are  at  first  styled  simply  the  Bishop's  brothers ;  and  even  Archibald,  the  head 
of  the  house,  and  the  undoubted  ancestor  of  the  chief  race  of  Douglas,  has  no  higher 

v  Wyntoun,  VIII.,  7. 


designation.     All  of  them  were  probably  provided  for,  whether  by  grants  of  ehurch 
lands,  or  as  beneficed  churchmen. q 

Upon  tlie  argument  of  Wyntoun,  derived  from  the  similarity  of  the  arms  of  the 
two  families,  his  editor  MacPherson  throws  discredit,  and  says,  it  "  shows  how  little 
"  people  then  knew  of  what  was  going  forward  even  among  themselves ;" r  and  he 
asserts  that  the  stars  formed  no  part  of  the  Douglases  arms  until  their  marriage  with 
the  heiress  of  the  Morays  of  Bothwell.  He  treats  the  authority  of  Godscroft  with 
contempt,  for  stating  that  "  the  ancient  arms  of  the  house  of  Douglas  were  three 
"  mollets  or  stars  only,  in  a  field  azure,  until  good  Sir  James  did  add  the  crowned 
"  heart."  But  Home  is  more  accurate  than  his  wont  in  this  matter;  and  when  he 
states  that  he  himself  had  seen  the  seal  of  William  of  Douglas  appended  to  an  inden- 
ture  of  1259,  ancl  that  "  the  arms  seemed  to  be  three  stars  or  mollets  at  the  upper 
"  end  thereof ;  but  I  cannot  be  bold  to  say  absolutely  they  were  so," — it  requires  some 
evidence  to  overthrow  so  circumstantial  a  statement.  In  the  present  case,  the  evi- 
dence  is  all  in  support  of  the  gossiping  chronicler  of  the  house  of  Douglas.  Mac- 
Pherson  says  the  "  original  arms  of  Douglas  were — argent,  a  chief  azure,  without  any 
"  figures  whatever,  as  appears  from  Froissart,  and  from  the  occasions  of  all  the  addi- 
"  tions  being  known  ;"  but  he  himself  states  that,  in  a  capital  manuscript  of  Frois- 
sart,  in  the  Royal  Library,  the  arms  of  Douglas  are  described — trois  estoilles  de 
gueulles  en  argent.  Unfortunately  no  coat  of  arms  of  the  family  of  Douglas  has 
come  down  to  us,  so  old  as  the  time  of  Sir  James,  the  companion  of  Bruce.  But  his 
nephew  William,  the  first  Earl  of  Douglas,  appears  to  have  been  curious  in  heraldry, 
and  was  probably  the  first  of  the  family  who  adopted  the  heart  (not  yet  crowned)  in 
commemoration  of  his  uncle's  honoured  trust.  He  had  three,  if  not  four  seals,  used 
at  different  periods  of  his  life,5  all  giving  arms  such  as  a  herald  of  that  day  would 

i  Alexander  seems  to  have  been  a  layman  and  he  had  aequired  property  there.     There  were 

sheriff  of  Elgin.     Hugh  and  Henry  were  ccr-  considerable  lands  in  the  neighbourhood  of  El- 

tainly  canons  of  the  Cathedral.     There  is  no  gin  auciently  and  long  possessed  by  Douglases, 

reason  to  doubt  that  Freskinus  (named  probably  whose  origin  cannot  be  at  all  traced,  unless  they 

after  his  uncle  of  Kerdal,  and  who  is  first  known  are  to  be  deduced  from  the  lay  brothers  of  Bishop

the  death  of  his  brother  the  Bishop  must  have  Probably  about  the  same  period  he  used  a  silver 

severed  his  connexion  with  that  country,  unless  stamp,  which  has  been  lately  found  near  Ber- 


have  blazoned  out  of  a  conjunction  of  a  coat  of  three  stars  only,  with  an  augmentation 
of  a  beart.  It  was  not  till  two  generations  after,  that  the  marriage  of  Arehibald  the 
Grim  with  the  heiress  of  Pettie  and  Bothwell  entitled  him  to  assume  the  arms  of  that 
branch  of  De  Moravia,  which  he  bore  on  an  escutcheon  of  pretence  over  his  own 
coat  of  Douglas  and  Galloway  quarterly. l 

The  length  to  which  these  genealogical  details  have  already  extended,  renders  it 
impossible  to  collect  the  niinute  facts  showing  the  intimacy  and  apparent  connexion 
betvveen  those  families,  and  tending  to  establish  that  the  House  of  Douglas  owed  the 
beginning  of  its  greatness  to  that  yet  undiscovered  affinity  with  the  De  Moravias 
which  led  to  its  adoption  of  their  arms. 

It  only  remains  to  explain  that  the  plan  whieh  has  been  adopted,  of  printing  with- 
out  abbreviations  from  an  excessively  abbreviated  MS.,  has  imposed  the  necessity  of 
determining  many  doubtful  words  and  passages u  that  might  have  been  left  in  their 
original  ambiguity  in  another  mode  of  editing.  The  accurate  student  of  these  anti- 
quities  should  not  take  such  readings  on  the  authority  of  an  editor ;  and  the  Tabula

ther  of  Bishop  Bricius,  occurs  ten  times  in  the 
older  chartulary  with  the  designation — "  vic  de 
Elgyn."  (JV.  28,  fol.  19.  N.  30,  fol.  15,fol.  39. 
N.  3l,/o/.  39.  N.  33,  fol.  42.  N.  35,  fol.  4 1 , 
fol.  18.  N.  95,  fol.  22.  N.  96,fol.  29.  JV.  120, 
fol.  21.)  He  occurs  twice,  written — "  vicec  de 
Elgyn"  (N.  3i,fol.  15.  N.  33,  fol.  18.),  and 
once^ — "  Alei  vicecomit  dc  Elgyn"  (N.  28,  fol. 
43).  Yet  at  N.  211,  tliis  person  and  his  brothtr 
witness  a  charter  of  Bishop  Bricius  as  "  Alex- 
andro  et  Henrico  canonicis  de  Spyny  fratribus 
is."  Are  we  to  hold  that  the  engrossers  of 
the  ancient  records  of  the  Bishopric,  thrice  wrote 
the  abbreviation  of  vicecomes  instead  of  that  for 
vicarius ;  or  is  it  to  be  admitted  that  the  church- 
man  and  Canon  of  the  Cathedral  held  also  the 
lay  oflice  of  Sheriif  of  the  Shire  ? 


will  be  found  to  facilitate  the  consultation  of  the  original  records.  Where  mistakes 
have  occurred,  they  cannot  be  attributed  to  haste  or  inadvertency.  To  bring  the 
Register  into  its  present  shape  has  cost  much  time  and  labour.  Unhappily  the 
thought  will  sometimes  intrude  that  they  might  have  been  better  bestowed. 

Four  charters  which  have  been  frequently  referred  to  in  the  preface,  are  printed  at 
its  conclusion,  from  the  originals  in  the  charter-room  at  Dunrobin.  On  the  last  leaf 
of  the  older  chartulary  is  the  following  memorandum  : —

8.  Charter  of  Alexander  II.,  of  Kyntessoch,  from  the  original  in  the  Advocates' 

Library. 

At page  471. 

9.  Extent  of  the  lands  of  Kylravoc,  from  the  original  at  Kilravock. 

At  the  End. 

10.  Map  of  Moray,  from  various  dravvings  by  Sir  Robert  Gordon  of  Straloch,  in  the 

Advocates'  Library,  Edinburgh. 

11.  Plate  I.  of  seals  of  the  Bishops  of  Moray,  referred  to  at  p.  xni  of  the  Preface. 

12.  Plate  II.  of  Bishops'  seals,  referred  to  at  p.  xiv  of  the  Preface.

dovan  et  Pethver.    c.  1284.    orig.  ibid.

dederat  Robertus  comes  de  Stradhern.    1234.    orig.  ibid.

parvam  Kynteffoch.     1236.   orig.  in  bibl.  advoc.  Edin.

kardyn  in  Kather  leuenas.    1251-69.  orig.  in  arckiris  Ducis  de  JMontrose.

Rofe  de  Kilravock.

Senefcalli.    1371.    ex  apograpko  in  arckivis  publicis  Edin.

^rie  forefte  Regie  de  Tarneway.    1371.  ex  apographo  in  arckivis  publicis  Edin.

De  eccleliis  de  Foreys  et  Dyk  • 

1 1  »W-  Dei  gratia  Rex  Scottorum  omnibus  probis  bominibus  tocius  terre  fue 
clericis  et  laicis  falutem  •  Sciant  prefentes  et  futuri  me  dediffe  et  concef- 
iiffe  et  hac  carta  mea  confirmaffe  Ricardo  epifcopo  de  Moravia  decem 
libras  de  firma  burgi  mei  de  Elgin  Jingulis  annis  percipiendas  •  donec  eccle- 
fiam  de  Foreys  et  ecclefiam  de  Dich  vacare  contigerit  •  Quas  cum  vaca- 
verint  dedi  et  concefii  prediclo  Ricardo  epifcopo  et  fuccefforibus  ejus  in 
perpetuum  in  liberam  et  puram  et  perpetuam  elemolinam  •  Ita  quidem

52  Alexander  Dei  gratia  Rex  Scottorum  omnibus  probis  hominibus  terre 
fue  clericis  et  laicis  falutem  •  Sciant  prefentes  et  futuri  me  conceffiffe  et

batalach  •  et  de  decimis  reddituum  que  mihi  debebantur  de  terris  infra 
parochias   predi6tarum   ecclefiarum   conftitutis   antequam   predi6te    terre

Confirmatio  • 

148  David  Dei  gratia  Rex  Scottorum  jufticiariis  realitatis  feu  regalitatis  comi- 
tatus  ODoravie  qui  pro  tempore  fuerint  et  aliis  jufticiariis  quibufcunque  ad

Preceptum  Regis  de  figillando  duas  literas  patentes  • 

172  Robertus  Dei  gratia  Rex  Scottorum  Alexandro  de  Cocburne  cuftodi  magni 
figilli  noftri  falutem  •  Mandamus  vobis  et  precipimus  quatenus  iigilletis 
figillo  noftro  magno  Alexandro  epifcopo  GDoravienfi  vel  fuis  attornatis 
duas  literas  patentes  •  unam  videlicet  dirigendam  dile6lis  fratribus  noftris 
Alexandro  Buchanie  et  Johanni  CDoravie  comitibus  ne  fe  intromittant  de 
caftro  de  Spyny  quovis  colore  amplius  •  et  aliam  tangentem  quandam  obli-

et  fingulos  canonicos  fuprafcriptos  legittime  et  peremptorie  noftris  literis

noftris  literis  contentas  incidiffe  declaramus  per  nos  et  eapitulum  noftrum 
modificandas  •  Et  prefentem  convocationem  ftatu  et  vigore  quibus  nunc

des  arcbidiaconus  Moravienfis  •  Jobannes  Ireland  Moravienfis  ecclefie  pre-

211  Bricius  Dei  gratia  epifcopus  CPoravienfis  univerfis  fancle  matris  ecclefie 
filiis  eternam  in  Domino  falutem  •  Noverit  univerfitas  veftra  nos  conceffiffe 
et  hac  carta  noftra  confirmaffe  Hugoni  de  CDoravia  domino  de  Duffus  et 
heredibus  fuis  ut  habeant  liberam  capellam  fuam  in  caftello  fuo  de  Duffus  • 
et  ad  fuftentationem  capellani  in  eadem  capella  defervientis  •  per  volunta-

290  Item  eodem  die  •  anno  etc-  octogefimo  tertio  •  die  et  menfe  quibus  fupra  •

301  Si  vaffallus  per  annum  et  diem  fteterit  dolofe  domino  fuo  mortuo  et  ad

305  Henricus  Dei  gracia  Rex  A.nglie  et  Francie  dominus  Hybernie  Regi 
Scotorum  falutem  ut  debite  faciatis  que  hortamur  •  Quomodo  antecef- 
fores  et  progenitores  noftri  Reges  Anglie  jure  fuperioris  et  direcli  dominii 
ab  antiquiffimis  retroa6lis  temporibus  videlicet  a  tempore  Locrini  filii  Brutij 
citra  Scocie  et  ipiius  Regibus  in  temporalibus  et  annexis  eifdem  prefu- 
erunt  •  et  ab  ipiis  Regibus  pro  regno  Scocie  et  ejufdem  regni  procertibus  a 
quibus  habere  volebant  legium  homagium  et  fidelitatis  juramentum  rece- 
perunt  •  vos  latere  nullatenus  dubitamus  •  et  ex  quo  hiidem  anteceffores 
et  progenitores  noftri  a  diftis  temporibus  citra  in  poffeffione  juris  et  do- 
minii  predidlorum  vel  quafi  fuerunt  •  Nos  eorundem  juris  et  dominii  pof- 
feffionem  continuantes  •  nichil  novi  innovantes  •  fed  jura  et  prerogativas 
corone  noftre  confervare  volentes  illefa  prout  ad  id  ex  virtute  per  nos 
preftiti  juramenti  fumus  obligati  •  idcirco  vos  tenore  prefencium  requiri- 
mus  monemus  et  hortamur  quatenus  confideratis  Chriitiani  fanguinis  effu- 
iione  aliifque  periculis  et  dampnis  que  ex  premiffis  fi  non  fierent  poffent

deceffores  jufti  et  legittimi  Reges  Scotorum  •  et  prefertim  Willelmus  qui 
Henrico  fecundo  et  Johanni  filio  fuo  •  et  Alexander  qui  Henrico  tercio

Ogilvy  de  eodem  et  Johannis  Grant  de  Fruychquhy  ineft  in  his  verbis — that  the  neiv  biggit

haue  ficlik  wyfs  and  poffeffion  of  paftoring,  faill  and  dowate  cafting,  gethis  making,  wattir 
dracht,  our  all  quhar  fra  the  well  of  Tobirquablach  lynaly  difcendand  down  to  the  heid  of  the 
meyr  burn  as  the  tenends  of  the  landis  of  Auchquhortheis  had  afor  the  feld  of  Flowdone  ;  cum

of  the  pen.     At  Auchindowne  and  Cromdell,  18  Dec.  1519.

851  Carta  feodifirmse  terrarum  de  Drumreocht  infra  paroebiam  de  Dyik  et  vic:  de  Elgyne  et  Forres,

Innes  de  Innermerkie.  Reddendo  L.2.  annuatim.  Teftibus  Georgio  Schaw  de  Knokhill,

dulle,  notariis.     Apud  Elgyne,  5  Nov.  1527.

4  H  Carta  Gavini  Epifcopi  Aberdonenfis  qua  (cum  confenfu  et  admortizatione  Itegis)  fundat  duas 
capellanias  in  ecclefia  cathcdrali  Moravienfi  et  duos  capellanos  dotat  50  marcis  annui  redditus 
e  terris  de  Querelwod  et  Lidget,  in  bonorem  Sanctse  Trinitatis  et  fanctorum  Columbae  et 
Tbom;e  martyris,  et  pro  falute  animarum  Regis  ejufque  predecefibrum  et  fucceflbrutn,  Alex- 
andri  Danbar  de  Veftfeld  militis  et  dominse  Elizabethas  Sutbirland  ejus  fponfae,  Epifcopi  paren- 
tum,  doraini  Roberti  Vellis  quondam  arcbidiaconi  Sancti  Andrese,  Gawini  Wach  quondam 
decani  Moravienfis,  magiltrorum  Jacobi  Lindefay  et  Jacobi  Brown  archidiaconi  et  decani  Abir- 
donenfis,  necnon  pro  falute  animae  Epifcopi  fundatoris,  aliorumque  Chriiti  fidelium  :  His  fta- 
tutis  fervatis  ;  Quod  dicti  duo  capellani  fmt  bonse  et  honeftae  converfationis  abfque  concubinis 
aut  focariis,  in  cantu  Gregariano  experti  et  difcantu  mediocriter  inftructi  et  docti  ;  et  quod 
indies  cum  difpofiti  fuerint  celebrabunt ;  prinms  in  infula  fancti  Columbe  pro  anima  Epifcopi  et 
ahis  predictis  animabus,  qui  et  cognomento  intitulabitur  decani  capellanus  ;  fecundus  vero  ad 
altare  Sancti  Thomae  in  cruce  ecclefia,-,  qui  capellanus  domini  Alexandri  Dunbar  vocabitur,  pro 
cujus  anima  et  dictae  Elizabeth  fponfte  fuse,  parentum  Epifcopi,  orabit.  Tenebuntur  etiam 
ambo  capellani  predicti  quotidie  in  choro  cum  choriftis  dictae  eccleGae  cathedralis  Moravienfis 
divina  fervitia  canere,  in  omnibus  boris  interefie  preterquam  horis  minutis,  fcilicet  prima,  tertia, 
fexta  et  nona ;  intererit  etiam  indies  capellanus  Sancti  Thoma?  in  celebratione  mifiie  celebratae 
cantu  Gregoriano  ad  dictum  altare  Sancti  Thomae  marthiris.  Preterea  dictus  primus  capellanus, 
decani  intitulatus,  annuatim  anniverfarium  unum  cum  milTa  de  requie,  placebo  et  dirige  pro 
anima  Epifcopi  in  die  obitus  ejus  per  canonicos  et  capellanos  chori  cantu  Gregoriano  celebrari 
faciet,  quo  die  canonicis  et  capellanis  in  dicto  fervitio  prefentibus  viginti  quatuor  folidos  inter 
eos  dividendos,  et  pauperibus  triginta  folidos,  de  illis  viginti  quinque  marcis  per  eum  percipien- 
dis  de  annuo  redditu  predicto,  perfolvet.  Secundus  vero  capellanus,  domini  Alexandri  Dunbar 
vocatus,  fimili  modo  aliud  anniverfarium  cum  mifla  de  requie,  plaeeho  et  diiiye  pro  animabus 
dictorum  domini  Alexandri  et  Elizabetb  Sudirland  fponfae  fuae,  genitorum  Epifcopi,  per  eofdem 
canonicos  et  capellanos  chori  die  decimo  menfis  Marcii  celebrari  caufabit,  quibus  fimihter 
riginti  quatuor  folidos,  et  pauperibus  eodem  die  triginta  folidos  de  viginti  quinque  marcis  per 
eum  recipiendis  dicti  principalis  annui  redditus,  annuatim  perfolvet,  et  boc  femel  in  anno  dun- 
taxat,  de  quo  annuo  redditu  principah  quinquaginta  marcarum  equaliter  inter  dictos  capellanos 
dividendarum  alter  eorum  vigtnti  marcas  ad  fuos  proprios  ufus  pro  feodo  five  falario  fuo  reti- 
nebit ;  et  quod  fupereft  de  principali  fumma  praeter  folutionem  pro  anniverfariis  et  pauperibus 
faciendam  extendeqs  ad  viginti  quinque  folidos  et  quatuor  denarios,  pro  pane,  vino,  cera,  et 
ornamentis  altarium  inter  ipfos  capellanos  duos  difponendum  equaliter  dividetur.  Et  ubi 
dictos  capellanos  fervitiis  communibus  chori  dictae  ecclefiae  Moravienfis  et  miflie  Sancti 
Thomae  interefle  et  fervire  ordinatum  eft,  dicti  capellani  cum  ceteris  chori  capellanis  commu- 
nium  diftribuciomim  fint  participes  et  illarum  fuam  partem  habeant.  Et  de  decem  marcis  pro 
dictis  anniverfariis,  pauperibus,  pane,  vino,  cera  et  altarium  ornamentis  difponendis  dicti  capel- 
lani  annuatim  compotum  et  rationem  decano  et  capitulo  ecclefiae  Moravienfis  reddant.  Pro- 
vifo  quod  dicti  duo  capellani  fint  immediate  fubjecti  et  obedientes  Decano  et  capitulo  ficut  alii 
capellani  et  cborift;e  dictre  ecelefiae  ;  et  tenebuntur  ad  continuam  refidenciam,  nec  abhinc  dif- 
cedent  fine  licentia  decani  et  capituli,  et  hoc  per  fpacium  viginti  quatuor  dierum  in  anno  ; 
viventque  honefte  abfque  concubinis  feu  focariis  ut  prius  dictum  eft,  cum  quibus  fi  depre- 
henfi  vel  notati  fuerint  et  per  decanum  et  capitulum  moniti  ad  defiftendum  ipfafque  con- 
cubinas   feu  focarias  amovendum,  et  mandatis   monitionibufque  hujufmodi  infra  quindecim

418  HEGISTRUM  MORAVIENSE. 

dies  non  paruerint,  a  fuis  capellaniis  per  decanum  et  capitulum  amovebuntur,  quibus  decano  et 
capitulo  in  locis  illorum  fic  amotorum,  alios  ydoneos  imponere  licebit  et  inftituere.  Provifo 
quoque  quod  dictse  capellanise  fint  incompatibiies  cum  quibufcunque  aliis  beneficiis  feu  officiis, 
exceptis  communibus  diftributionibus  cbori  cum  ceteris  capellanis  pro  eorum  refidentia  et  fer- 
viciis.  Jure  patronatus  Epifcopo  fundatori  refervato  et  poll  ejus  deceffum  decano  Moravienfi 
dato,  quo  deficiente,  capitulo ;  capitulo  etiam  non  prefentante,  ad  Epifcopum  devoluturo.

1529.

458  Carta  feodifirrase  ali  Epifcopo,  fuper  prefentatione  Regia,  data  Johanni  Campbell  de  Caldour 
militi,  quinque  mercatarum  terrarum  de  Litill  Urquhany  in  baronia  de  Arclauch,  vic:  de  Narne, 
quse  fuerunt  quondam  magiftri  Johannis  Caldure  precentoris  Roffenfis,  haftardi,  et  in  mamis 
Regis  devenerunt  per  ejus  deceflum  ahfque  legitimo  herede  de  corpore  fuo,  ratione  baftardiae  :

463  A  Deed  by  which  Alexander  Innes  of  Cottis  renuncis,  difchargis  and  overgives  in  favour  of 
Jhone  Bifchop  of  Moray,  the  office  of  Conftabularie  of  the  fortalice  and  caftle  of  Spynie, 
yairdis  orcheardis  and  all  and  fundrie  utheris  within  the  precinct  of  the  faid  place,  which 
umquhil  Alexander  Lord  of  Spynie  and  Lord  of  the  Regality  thereof; — by  his  charter,  of  the 
dait  at  the  Cannogait  the  18  December  1599,  confirmed  by  a  charter  under  the  great  feal,  25 
December  1599,  and  by  a  charter  of  umquhil  Alexander  Bifchop  of  Moray  with  confent  of  the 
deane  and  chapter,  of  the  dait  at  Elgin  \_  ~]  day  of  Junii  1607, — granted  to  umquhil  Jhone 
Innes  of  Lewchers  in  lyfrent  and  to  the  faid  Alexander  Innes  in  fee,  together  with  ane  fee  of 
ane  hundreth  pounds  yeirlie  out  of  the  fruits  profits  and  dewties  of  the  faid  lordihip  and  rega- 
litie  and  of  the  lands,  baronies,  tounes  and  fifchingis  perteining  to  the  bifchoprick  befor  the  act 
of  annexatioun  ;  with  the  privilege  of  keiping  of  the  wod,  fchaw  or  forreft  of  Spynie,  with  9  bollis 
victual  for  the  fame  ;  with  the  keiping  of  the  Loch  of  Spynie  and  power  to  take  and  flay  fifches 
fwimming  therein  ;  and  with  power  to  take  peittes  and  uther  feuall  in  the  Laverock  mofs  and 
in  the  mures  adjacent  thereto  ;  and  all  uther  fies,  dewties,  privileges,  cafualities  and  immuni- 
ties  perteining  to  the  faid  office  of  Conftabularie.  A  procuratory  of  refignatioun  is  contained 
at  the  end.  Witnefles  Mr  Jhone  Kinneir  and  Mr  Francis  Hay  writer  to  his  Majefties  fignet, 
William  Moray  of  Dunern,  and  Androw  Aytoun  of  Logie  advocat.  At  Edinburgh,  20  No- 
vember  1623.

tione  annexi  •  et  qui  frequentius  pro  Crilti  nomine  inter  malivolas  animas

pendere  famulatum  •  Dilectis  itaque  filijs  noftris  abbati  et  monacbis  de
